hawaiian_text: A make ‘o Puali‘i, ho‘i akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī, noho ihola lāua, ‘a‘ohe ‘ai o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka ‘ai. I ia wā, e noho ana ‘o  ‘Ama‘u he ali‘i no O‘ahu nei, ma Waikīkī kahi i noho ai, hele maila kekahi kanaka no Honouliuli  mai ā hiki ma Waikīkī, e noho ana ke ali‘i. ‘Ōlelo  akula ia: “E ke alii ē\! He ‘oi kahi keiki ‘u‘uku ikaika  loa, ua make kona makua kāne a ua kiola ‘ia kona  po‘o i kai loa, he wahi lō‘ihi loa, ‘elima mile ka  lō‘ihi. A lohe o ‘Ama‘u, aia kona ikaika a make au iā  ia, akā, i ‘ole au e make iā ia ‘a‘ohe ona ikaika. Iā ia  e ‘ōlelo ana ma Waikīkī, ua lohe nō ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo nona.
gemma-3n-e4b-it-gguf-q4kxl-32k-maui_tran: The death of Puali'i, Nāmakaokapāo'o returned until his mother, Pōka'ī, was sitting there, and Nāmakaokapāo'o had no food to eat. At that time, ‘Ama‘u, a chief of O‘ahu who lived in Waikīkī, had a man come from Honouliuli all the way to Waikīkī, where the chief resided. He said, “O mighty chief! This is a very strong little boy; his father is dead, and his head was cast out to sea, a very long one, five miles long. And ‘Ama‘u heard this, and I am strong and will die by him, but I will not die by him because he has no strength. As he was speaking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o heard these words.”
gemma-3n-e4b-it-gguf-q4kxl-32k-maui_comm: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>The death of Puali'i, Nāmakaokapāo'o returned until his mother, Pōka'ī, was sitting there, and Nāmakaokapāo'o had no food to eat. At that time, ‘Ama‘u, a chief of O‘ahu who lived in Waikīkī, had a man come from Honouliuli all the way to Waikīkī, where the chief resided. He said, “O mighty chief! This is a very strong little boy; his father is dead, and his head was cast out to sea, a very long one, five miles long. And ‘Ama‘u heard this, and I am strong and will die by him, but I will not die by him because he has no strength. As he was speaking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o heard these words.”</translation>
<commentary>
**Paragraph 10:** • This passage serves as a narrative bridge, introducing new information and foreshadowing future events within the story of Nāmakaokapāo'o. It establishes a crucial detail regarding Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o’s lineage and a potential source of conflict or motivation for his actions. 

– **Puali'i's Death & Significance:** The death of Puali'i is presented as an event that disrupts the established order. It’s important to note that while Puali'i was previously portrayed positively, this event seems to have a profound impact on Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o and his relationship with his mother.  The fact that he died at sea suggests a disruption of the land, linking back to themes of disruption found in many Hawaiian stories. 
– **‘Ama‘u's Speech & Power Dynamics:** The introduction of ‘Ama‘u, a chief from O‘ahu, is significant. He speaks of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o’s father being cast out to sea and boasts about his own strength, claiming that he would die by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o but not the other way around due to a lack of strength on Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o’s part. This speech highlights several themes:
    – **Strength and Power:**  The concept of *ike* (knowledge, power) is central in Hawaiian culture. ‘Ama‘u attempts to establish his own authority by claiming superior strength – a common motif in heroic tales where characters are tested. However, the implication that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's strength transcends physical prowess is crucial.
    – **Ancestral Connection & Lineage:** The mention of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo’o’s father being cast out to sea connects him to a wider narrative beyond the immediate story, implying potential ancestral ties and conflicts with other islands or communities.  This reinforces that the events within this narrative are not isolated.
    – **The Power of Words:** The passage emphasizes the impact of ‘Ama‘u's words on Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o. This is a common feature in Hawaiian storytelling, where speech can have a powerful influence – sometimes even shaping reality. 
– **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o’s Reception of Information:** The fact that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo’o *hears* these words from afar suggests he is increasingly aware of the world outside his immediate environment and the complexities surrounding his identity.  He isn't merely reacting to events, but absorbing information about himself and his lineage – a crucial step in his development as a character.
– **Allegorical Interpretation:** The act of casting Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo’o’s father into the sea can be interpreted allegorically. It may represent banishment or exile, highlighting themes of separation from ancestral lands and cultural heritage which are common in Polynesian narratives. Furthermore it could foreshadow a conflict between generations where new ways of thinking clash with established traditions. 

</commentary>
reference_translation: When Puali‘i died, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back  to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and the two lived together,  but Nāmakaokapāo‘o had nothing to eat. At that  time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu in Waikīkī,  where he lived. A man of Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was found. The man said,  “Chief, there is a little boy who is amazingly strong.  He killed his father and threw his head in the  ocean a really long distance away, five miles off.”  When ‘Ama‘u heard this, he said, “We’ll see how  strong he is if he kills me. But if he doesn’t kill me,  he isn’t strong at all.” When he said this in Waikīkī,  Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard what he was saying about  him.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14**• From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of  Christianity’s defeat over the ‘Ai Kapu, with   Nāmakaokapāo‘o representing progressive   Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his  mother, Pōka‘ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians’ futile attempts to hold onto ‘Ai Kapu culture.
